sections.heading: Electronic Noses: From Advanced Materials to Sensors
Wenwen Hu, Liangtian Wan, Yingying Jian, Cong Ren, Ke Jin, Xinghua Su, Xiaoxia Bai,
Hossam Haick,* Mingshui Yao,* and Weiwei Wu*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/admt.201800488
on receptors located in the nasal cavity.[2] Molecules carrying specific odors enter through the turbinate bones to touch the olfactory epithelium containing nerve cells and their hair-like endings, trigeminal endings, and supporting cells (Figure 1a).[2] Odorant molecules are absorbed by the olfactory epithelium mucus, diffuse onto the cilia of the olfactory cells, and interact with a specific receptor on its surface, probably complexing with odor-binding proteins thereby depolarizing the receptor cell. Simultaneously, an electrochemical potential is provoked and transmitted to the olfactory bulb along the axon direction and thence to the higher brain centers where the signals are interpreted in terms of the character and intensity of the odor (Figure 1b).[3] After learning/ training, the human brain can remember different potentials/signals caused by different odorants molecules, which endows human beings with an ability to recognize odors.
Inspired by the olfactory system, artificial devices that combine arrays of chemical sensors with pattern recognition techniques, commonly termed “electronic nose” (e-nose), have been explored for use as inexpensive chemical point detectors. Proposed by Dodd and Persaud at Warwick University in UK in 1982,[4] this e-nose technology has been further developed
Artificial olfaction, i.e., e-nose, plays a critical function in robotics by mimicking the human olfactory organ that can recognize different smells that correlate with a range of fields, including environment monitoring, disease diagnosis, public security affairs, agricultural production, food industry, etc. The advances in the artificial olfaction (electronic nose) technology and its applications are concisely reviewed herein. Three main elements are investigated and presented, with an emphasis on the emerging sensors and algorithm of the artificial neural network in the relevant fields. The first element is the diverse applications of e-nose in medical care, food industry, environment monitoring, public security affairs, and agricultural production. The second element is the investigation of the sensors in e-nose and representative and promising advances, which is the building block of e-nose through mimicking the olfactory receptors. The third element is the introduction to the algorithm of the artificial neural network to serve in the recognition of the pattern of odors (i.e., their chemical profiles). Promises and challenges of the separately reviewed parts and the combined parts are presented and discussed. Ideas regarding further orientation and development of the e-nose system are also considered.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The olfactory system in animals has many purposes, including the detection of hazards, pheromones, and food.[1] It integrates with other organs, especially the brain, to form the sense of odor.[1] Olfaction occurs when odorants bind to specific sites
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800488 (2 of 38)
www.advmattechnol.de
and reviewed by many researchers in the past decades.[1,5] In 1993, Gardner and Bartlett first defined the e-nose as ‘an instrument, which comprises an array of electronic chemical sensors with partial specificity and an appropriate pattern-recognition system, capable of recognizing simple or complex odors.[1] Most e-noses use interactive sensor-arrays (step 1) that react to analytes on the sensitive materials’ surface accompanying with the adsorption, desorption and/or reversible reaction, etc., (Figure 2). Meanwhile, the specific responses between the analytes and the sensors array are recorded and transformed into readable digital values (step 2), which can be computed based on statistical models (step 3) to achieve the recognition (step 4) of different odors.[6]
With the boom and wide application of Internet of things (IoT), the building block of IoT, sensor network has a huge demand on e-noses that perform qualitative or quantitative analysis with various advantages in odor measurement. The main advantages include high consistency and reproducibility of the sensing results, short time for obtaining results and high throughput of analyses, permanent availability and reliability, nondestructive and global analysis of an odor/aroma, fingerprint results as human assessment with higher performance, results correlated with human perception due to multivariate data treatment, wide tolerance of gas temperature, no limitation of toxicity of analytes, inexhaustibility forever for continuous monitoring, etc. Those features not only ensure the practical application of e-nose, but shed the light for the development of e-nose technology in the future.
Till now, chemoresistor,[7] field effect transistors (FET),[8] quartz crystal microbalance (QCM),[9] and solid state electrochemical sensors (SSES)[10] have been demonstrated and welldeveloped as promising candidates of the sensing units of e-nose. This article gives a concise review of the advances in the materials used for e-nose technology and its applications. The review focuses on three main elements of the e-nose technology. The first element is the various demands of e-nose technology in the medical care, food industry, environment monitoring, public security affairs, and agricultural production. The second element is the R&D of advanced materials used to build the sensors composing the e-nose technology. The third element is the introduction to the algorithm for recognitions and classifications to the odors. Promises and challenges of the advances of each element are presented and discussed. Several thinkings and ideas regarding further orientation and development of e-nose system are also discussed.

sections.heading: 2. Applications of the e-Nose
sections.text: By mimicking and/or upgrading the olfactory function of human beings, the e-nose technology has been widely used in many fields. Representative advances are introduced in the following parts.

sections.heading: 2.1. Medical Care
sections.text:
e-noses have been successfully used for diagnosis of health conditions via detection and classification of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into one or combination of body fluids released as a result of a disease evolvement in the human body.[5a,b,11] In general, exhaled breath, skin/sweat, feces, urine, saliva, breast milk, and intestinal gas are the one or a combination of the secretion pathways of VOCs emission.[12]
Hossam Haick, Professor at the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, is an expert in the field of nanotechnology and smart sensors. He is the founder and leader of several European consortiums for the development of advanced generations of nanosensors for disease diagnosis. His research interests include nanomaterialbased chemical (flexible)
sensors, electronic skin, nanoarray devices for screening, diagnosis, and monitoring of disease, breath analysis, volatile biomarkers, and molecular electronic devices.
Mingshui Yao received his B.S. degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology (2009) from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT) and Ph.D. in Materials Science (2014), supervised by Prof. Fangli Yuan from the Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). He worked as an assistant
professor (2014–2018) in Prof. Gang Xu’s group at the Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, CAS. He is now a Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) postdoctoral fellow in Kyoto University, supervised by Prof. Susumu Kitagawa. His major field is low temperature and highly selective gas sensors based on metal oxides (MOXs), metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and their composites (MOX-MOFs, MOF-on-MOFs, etc.).
Weiwei Wu received his B.S. degree in Material Chemistry (2007) and Ph.D. degree in Materials Physics and Chemistry (2014), supervised by Prof. Yong Qin from Lanzhou University, China. He was a postdoctoral fellow in Technion-Israel Institute of Technology (2015–2016), supervised by Prof. Hossam Haick. Currently, he is an
associate professor in School of Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology, Xidian University, China. His research mainly focuses on nanomaterials and nanodevices.

e-noses based on sensor arrays made with Pt, Pd, Rh, and Pt-Y functionalized WO3 nanofibers (NFs) have shown good ability to discriminate between simulated breath of a halitosis patient and healthy people (Figure 3a).[5b] This discrimination could be seen through the principle component analysis (PCA) map that shows complete separation between the two studied groups (Figure 3b).[5b] By training chemoresistor arrays based on molecularly modified gold nanoparticles (GNPs) via simulated breath of lung cancer (Figure 3c) it is possible to use the same technology for diagnosis of lung cancer in real patients (Figure 3d).[13] e-nose that is based on a combination of chemoresistors based on molecularly modified GNPs and singlewall carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) has been clinically proven as a successful tool for the diagnosis of gastric cancer and the

surveillance of the precancerous lesions, which is superb for the early detection and prevention of cancer (Figure 3e).[14] More impressively, similar combined sensors array is able to detect and discriminate between 17 diseases from 1404 subjects, with high accuracy (86% in average; Figure 3f,g).[15] Of great importance, by deliberate control between the sensors array and machine learning approaches it is possible not only to detect and discriminate between the various diseases but also to minimize the effects of primary demographic and environmental confounding factors, Inc., sex, age, smoking habits, and geographical location on the diagnosis/classification results.[15] These results point out for the possibility that the e-nose diagnosis/classification has the potential to be universal, generalizable, and promising approach for practical application and commercialization.
Recently, Shehadeh et al., has designed, fabricated and studied silicon nanowire based FETs for disease diagnosis via breath samples.[16] These sensors have the advantages of being easily integrated into the existing technologies, their device fabrication processes are standard, reproducible and scalable in the microelectronics industry, their power consumption is relatively low, they are relatively cheap to fabricate, and can be adjusted to sense various analytes in various phases through simple molecular modification processes (Figure 3h).[16,17] These devices could provide an invaluable increase in the number of multiple sensing features that operate as “virtual sensors”, viz., a set of independent sensing signals extracted from the electrical measurements of the device, and can be monitored separately as if they were the individual sensors. This behavior of the device leads to a decrease in the number of sensors needed for classification, and thus simplifies the system required in terms of supporting circuitry and infrastructure. Using these devices, it is possible to classify breath simulants of lung cancer, gastric cancer and other respiratory diseases. The simulants can be separated with a high accuracy (>80% in most cases, and >90% in some cases). In addition, real breath samples of patients suffering from gastric cancer, lung cancer as well as noncancerous lung conditions represented by asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease have been successfully diagnosed. It is able to differentiate breath samples of each disease from a control group, as well as each other with an accuracy of >80% in most cases (Figure 3i).[16] The VOCs concentrations from human breath and body always at ppb even lower level, which asks for well-tailored and inter-reactive sensor arrays with ultrahigh performance instead of commercial sensors. Table 1 summarizes the existed sensing technologies and its accuracies for detecting different kinds of diseases.[5b,13–16,18]

sections.heading: 2.2. Food Industry
sections.text:
Many advances have been achieved, based on high performance sensor arrays and pattern recognition algorithm
(Figure 4). As shown in Figure 4a,[19] an e-nose system has been used to monitor the shelf life of tomato by sensing the aromatic VOCs due to post-harvesting, respiration, fermentation, and phenolic oxidation.[20] The shelf life of tomato in a box can be clearly discriminated by detecting emitted VOCs in the headspace with analysis of PCA (Figure 4b) and Linear discriminant analysis (LDA) (Figure 4c).[19] Fungi contamination in peaches could be detected through analysis of VOCs. The 3 common spoilage fungi including Botrytis cinerea, Monilinia fructicola, and Rhizopus stolonifera for 24, 48, and 72 h, can be well discriminated (Figure 4d–f, respectively).[21] Meat spoilage can also be tracked by e-nose (Figure 4g).[22] The different spoilage related VOCs (biogenic amines) and NH3[23] generate different responses (Figure 4h).[22] When the meats are stored at 30 °C for 20 h, the responses are different for beef, pork, fish, and chicken, which means different spoilages (Figure 4i).[22] In addition, the impact injury of apples and the shelf life of milk are able to be monitored by e-nose (Figure 4j,[24]k[25]). Moreover, the brand and/or the place of origin can be recognized by e-nose (Figure 4l), e.g., the tobacco types and cigarette brands can be identified by a composite polymer based sensors (Figure 4m).[26] The VOCs concentrations emitted in the food aging, spoilage process are ppm level,[21,24,27] which lets many commercial sensors usable and as a powerful tool in food industry, and other representative advances are summarized in Table 2.[19,21,22,26,28]
2.3. Environment Monitoring
Continuously on-line/in situ detection of gas is desired to most environmental monitoring applications, e.g., the identification of toxic wastes including carbon monoxide (CO), sulfur dioxide (SO2), ammonia, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), ozone (O3); air quality testing is mainly nitric oxide (NO), nitrous oxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), sulfur dioxide (SO2).[29] Soil/water pollution mainly includes methane (CH4), ammonia, NO, SO2; the factory emission detection is mainly about toluene, H2S, SO2; vehicle exhaust control of CO, CO2, NO, NO2; indoor volatile organic compounds are mainly formaldehyde (HCHO), benzene and acetone, etc.[29]
Toward this end, many kinds of e-noses have been applied to sense odors and gases. An unmodified graphene-based sensor has been demonstrated to successfully discriminate both chemical diversity (Figure 5a) and chemical VOCs (Figure 5b) at room temperature by taking advantage of its intrinsic, broad selective nature of the graphene, which is important and valuable for indoor VOCs detection and monitoring.[30] The p–n junction between CuO and ZnO mesocrystals has been utilized to detect hazardous H2S, NO2, CO, acetone, NH3, and explosive H2 as shown in Figure 5c,d. The detection of H2S can reach 100 ppb level (Figure 5e) and all the

Piedrahita and the co-authors have demonstrated a quantification system that can provide personal exposure measurements and uncertainties for CO2, O3, NO2, and CO. This type of quantification approach provides access to air quality monitoring to a wider audience of scientists and citizens.[34] Representative advances are summarized in Table 3.[29j,p,31–33,35]

sections.heading: 2.4. Public Security
sections.text:
The public security, especially anti-terrorism, becomes extremely urgent. The applications, in this field, mainly focus on the detection of the explosives and/or the nerve agents. Normally, the vapor pressure of explosives, e.g., 2-methyl-1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNT), 1,3,5-trinitroperhydro-1,3,5-triazine (RDX), octahydro-1,3,5,7-tetranitro-1,3,5,7-tetrazocine (HMX) are 9 ppb, 4.9 ppt, and 0.25 ppt, respectively.[36] Therefore, the detection of explosives needs ultra-sensitive sensors. The vapor pressure of the nerve agents is higher, but almost all the researches are based on the simulant gas, e.g., dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP), tricresyl phosphate (TCP), methyl dichlorophosphate (MDCP), trimethyl phosphate (TMP), etc.[37] The requirements to e-nose in this field can be summarized as: fast response and recovery, ultra-sensitivity, easy miniaturization for field application, perform real-time high-throughput analysis, elimination both false positive and false negative results, robust, and not prone to drift. Detection of explosives and nerve agents has been achieved through several approaches including doped or surface modified sensitive materials, regulated contact barrier, absorbent materials with unique pore size. The addition of surface organic functional group, especially amidogen, on sensing materials can effectively extend the limit of detection of the sensors array to ppq level (Figure 6g–k).[39] Besides the above sensors, another reliable way for detecting nerve toxic gas is metal–organic framework (MOFs) based ChemFET. Exposure of DMMP down to 3 ppb causes shifts in the contact potential difference (CPD) of UiO-66-NH2 covered electrodes (Figure 6l,m).[40] Most recent developments are summarized in the Table 4.[36,38–41] However, how to enhance and advance the limit of detection with the assurance of high accuracy, the speed of response and recovery and the minimization of device are still challenging.

sections.heading: 2.5. Agricultural Production
sections.text:
The applications of e-noses in the agriculture field is meant to replace the slow and difficult laboratory analysis with fast and easy in-field e-nose analysis. For the crop monitoring, mandarin maturity has been precisely detected by e-nose (Figure 7a–c).[42] Concentrated VOCs emitted by mandarin are collected and measured by e-nose (PEN2) and the analyzed by PCA and LDA method as shown in Figure 7b,c, respectively. The LDA method has successfully distinguished the mandarin from 0 to 60 days, which demonstrates the success in maturity recognition for saving lots of labor force. The VOCs emitted by pests and/or diseases attacked plants have much greater amounts and variety of VOCs than nonattacked plants. As shown in Figure 7d–f, the cucumber, pepper and tomato can be detected their healthy conditions through simply measure the VOCs.[43] For the raw materials monitoring, soil quality is important for the growth of crops. Diesel polluted, petrol polluted and unpolluted soils can be discriminated by e-nose (TGS Figaro) in an off-line way as shown in Figure 7g,h, which is promising for further developing an in situ detection to ensure the quality of soil.[44] In addition, the odors emitted from wastewater treatment plant can be clearly separated by e-nose from BioInlet to Sludge stage as shown in Figure 7i, which means the quality of water used in agriculture can probably be evaluated by
e-nose.[45] The representative advances are summarized in Table 5.[44–46]

sections.heading: 3. The Sensors in the e-Nose System
sections.text: Gas sensors are the building blocks of the e-nose. The better performance of the sensor is, the higher quality of the e-nose achieves. The evaluation of the sensor follows several criteria: high sensitivity that determines the limit of detection; reasonable selectivity and specificity; fast response and recovery; robustness, not prone to drift or the drift can be compensated; ability of effective multiparameters extraction; low cost and easy to use; and good repeatability and long-term stability. To meet all these requirements, various kinds of sensors are developed with well-designed materials and working principles, they will be introduced as follow.

sections.heading: 3.1. Chemoresistive Gas Sensor
sections.text:
A chemoresistor is a material that changes its electrical resistance in response to changes in the nearby chemical environment. A basic chemoresistor consists of a sensing material that bridges the gap between two electrodes or coats a set of interdigitated electrodes. The resistance between the electrodes

can easily be measured. The sensing material has an inherent resistance that can be modulated by the presence or absence of the analyte. During the exposure, analytes interact with the sensing material. These interactions cause changes in the resistance reading. In some chemoresistors, the resistance changes simply indicate the presence of analyte. In another aspect, the resistance changes are proportional to the amount of analyte present. This allows for the amount of analyte present to be measured.
Nanomaterials with large surface area are superb as the sensitive materials of chemoresistor. Monodispersed SnO2 quantum dots (QDs) (≈3.5 nm) (Figure 8a)[47] has achieved high responses to typical VOCs at 350 °C, of which the value exceeding 1000 can be achieved for 50 ppm of ethanol gas (Figure 8b–d).[47] When the exposure crystal planes of nanocrystal are regulated, the sensitivity could be purposely controlled (Figure 8e) due to varied activity originating from exposed atoms, dangling bonds, crystal edges, corners, etc.[48] Heterojunction between well-designed dual phases materials is effective for tuning and enhancing the sensing performance ascribing to a synergetic effect, e.g., the ZnO and SnO2 heterojunction (Figure 8f,g) with a band banding and Te nanowires@SnO2 nanowires hierarchical nanostructure (Figure 8h) can achieve enhanced gas sensing performance (the insert of Figure 8h).[28e,49] When the sensing materials have more complicated structures (e.g., a multishell sphere), they play the role of microreactors to control the decomposition, which induces a synergetic combination between the effective inward diffusion through thin and semipermeable shells, and their subsequent dissociation into smaller and more active species by catalysts on the yolk or inner part of the shell as shown in Figure 8i.[50]
The ability of anti-interferon, viz., the specificity, is highly required for sensors. Several strategies are exploited to improve it. First, the most effective way for specific detection of gas is inducing the phase change of which the resistances are dramatic different. For instance, arrays of Pd nanotubes (Figure 9a), can reach the rapid, selective and sensitive detection of H2 detection at room temperature, ascribing to the formation a solid solution of Pd/H (α-phase) or a palladium
hydride (β-phase) between adsorbed H2 and Pd as shown in Figure 9b.[51] However, this strategy is quite limited for sensitive materials. Second, to cover the surface with a layer of molecular or MOFs are known to eliminate the humidity effect on semiconductive polymer and metal oxide, respectively.[52] The modified water-detach and float-attach (WDFA) method (Figure 9c) can eliminate the effect of humidity when the humidity is lower than 350 ppm (Figure 9d) at room temperature.[52b] The bimetallic ZIF-CoZn MOF sheath on ZnO (Figure 9e) processes good thermal stability (ZIF-8(Zn)) and excellent thermally catalytic ability on ZnO (ZIF-67(Co)), as well as hydrophobic channels to not only improve selectivity (good anti-humidity) (Figure 9f), but also enhance its response, response and recovery behavior, and working temperature (Figure 9g).[52a] Third, when nanostructure combines with constituent regulation (elements mapping as shown in Figure 9i), the humidity poisoning effect can be well screen accompanied with acceptable analyte sensing performance degrading as shown in Figure 9h.[53]
To recognize gas through enhancing the selectivity and specificity on single sensor is the long-term bottlenecks of traditional chemoresistive gas sensors due to the limited extracted sensing parameters, i.e., insufficient freedoms for pattern recognition. Assembly of sensors to be cross-reactive sensor arrays have been demonstrated as a short cut to achieve this goal. As shown in Figure 10a, the carbon nanotube/hexaperi-hexabenzocoronene bilayers are fabricate between two electrodes for selectively detection of decane, octane, hexane, ethanol, and water (Figure 10b) with clear discrimination by PCA (Figure 10c).[54] The good response to nonpolar VOCs of this sensor makes them success in a further application in disease diagnosis. GNPs covered with various kinds of thiols also achieve great success in VOCs sensing. When the thiols on the GNPs surface contact VOCs, the molecular chains swell or shrink to change the interspace of GNPs that affect the electrons hopping between GNPs leading to the resistance changes. This kind of sensor arrays are applied successfully in disease diagnosis and commercialized by Sunshine company (Figure 10d).[55] The 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene (HHTP) based 2D Cu-CAT MOFs with regular pores

(≈1.8 nm) is successfully demonstrated to be a chemoresistive sensor arrays that can reliably distinguish five categories of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) (Figure 10e,f).[56] The recent representative advances are summarized in the Table 6.[29d,35j,52a,57]

sections.heading: 3.2. FET-Based Gas Sensor
sections.text:
The FET is a device that controls the flow of carriers from the source to drain by regulating the size and shape of a “conductive channel” created and influenced by voltage applied across
the gate and source terminals.[8b] When FET works as a gas sensor, the gas molecules change the nature of the conductive channel or induce charge transfer to change the electrical characteristics including threshold voltage, subthreshold swing, mobility, etc.,[17d] which means the FET based gas sensor intrinsically has the ability of multiparameters extraction, i.e., more freedoms for pattern recognition than these of the chemoresistor.[17d,58] Generally, the FET gas sensors have low working temperature and high sensitivity.[59]
Gas analytes can affect the conductive channel of 2D materialbased FET gas sensor effectively due to their atomic thickness, which leads to fast response and recovery, high sensitivity, and
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800488 (14 of 38)
www.advmattechnol.de
good signal-to-noise ratio. Phosphorene nanosheet (PNS) has been demonstrated its potential applications in gas sensing in a dry air environment (Figure 11a).[60] NO2 shows dramatically different sensing behavior (down to 20 ppb) comparing with those of H2, CO, H2S as shown in Figure 11b,c.[60] Meanwhile, the sensing behaviors can be tuned by precisely controlling the layers of phosphorene nanosheet. As shown in Figure 11d When metal particles with different work functions (e.g., Y, Sc, Ag, Au, Pd, and Pt) load on the 2D nanomaterials (e.g., MoS2 and WSe2), the gas sensing behaviors to H2 including threshold voltage and carrier concentration can be regulated (Figure 11e,f).[41h] Pure Ti3C2Tx MXene based gas sensor (Figure 11g) is also demonstrated with ultrahigh limit of the detection and signal-to-noise ratio due to the superior gas adsorption properties on the hydroxyl groups of Ti3C2Tx (Figure 11h).[61] The functionalization of the insulation layer (Figure 11i) also can greatly tune the sensing behavior of FET sensor during different treatment time (Figure 11j), especially to NO2 (Figure 11k).[62] However, the scalability and repeatability in fabrication process, the stability of sensing performance, and the anti-interferon (e.g., humidity, O2) ability are still problematic for these ultrasensitive and novel nanomaterials based gas sensors.
Loading probe materials on host materials as a hybrid material is an effective way for enhancing the selectivity. A series of Si NW FETs modified by different molecules with different functional groups (Figure 12a), Inc., phenyl, carboxyl, ester, alkyl groups, are developed to perfectly recognize 11 kinds of VOCs under the assistance of ANN as shown in Figure 12b.[17d] Singlestranded DNA (DNA-NT) modified CNT (DNA-NT) (Figure 12c) is also exploited to fabricate a FET gas sensor that has the ability to discriminate highly similar molecules (e.g., structural isomers and enantiomers) and subtle variations in complex vapors (e.g., mixtures of structural isomers and mixtures of many volatile organic compounds characteristic of humans) as shown in Figure 12d,e.[63] The mouse olfactory receptor proteins (i.e., mOR174-9 respond to eugenol, mOR203-1 respond to 2-heptanone, mOR256-17 respond to cyclohexanone) have also been purified, solubilized and then biofunctionalized to CNTs to be a FET gas sensor which can detect vapor analytes under ambient conditions, with sensor responses that are reversible, repeatable, and durable (Figure 12f).[64] Furthermore, taking advantage of the different working mode of FET (Figure 12g),[65] when the FET works at deep enhancement-mode, the nonspecific sensitivity to all gases from the nanowires can be suppressed, and the specific and selective response can be generated only when their surface covered with discrete metal nanoparticles (Figure 12h–j).[65] This may be a very effective approach to achieve gas sensing with decoupled signals.

A very unique thing for FET gas sensor is the ability of extracting multiparameters from single sensor. A FET sensor based an ambipolar semiconducting polymer, poly(diketopyrrolopyrrole-terthiophene) (PDPPHD-T3), has been developed to achieve the detection of xylene isomer vapors (Figure 13a–e).[58] The ambipolar FET generates multiple sensing parameters in electron and hole conduction toward xylene isomers. By using a combined pattern recognition method along with multiple sensing parameters obtained from a single ambipolar FET, the chemically and structurally similar xylene isomers as well as binary and ternary xylene mixture solvents can be identified perfectly. The sensing mechanism has been studied by DFT calculations with the results showing that both highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels of the polymer increase with xylene isomers adsorption. As a result, the hole injection barriers of the ambipolar FET decreases, facilitating hole transport, whereas the electron injection barriers increase, suppressing the electron transport. However, for some polymers based OFET sensors, the responses of NH3 and triethylamine are always with the price of recovery. Introducing chemical reaction into the polymer sensing process is

sections.heading: 3.3. Solid State Electrochemical Gas Sensor
sections.text:
The solid-state electrochemical gas sensing techniques, which are classified into four categories (viz., equilibrium potentiometric sensors (EPS), mixed potentiometric sensors (MPS), amperometric sensors and impedancemetric gas sensors), have been proved as selective, accurate and reliable methods for sensing gaseous chemical compounds in various environments. Meanwhile, the stability of SSES has been proven, which ensures its successful commercialization, mostly working at high temperature, e.g., vehicle exhaust gas sensor, oxygen sensor, etc. A summary of the SSES is given in Tables 8–11 and the representative works are introduced as follow.
The equilibrium potentiometric sensors (summarized in
example is the CO2 sensor based on KCO3 electrolyte,[70] in which gas analyte equilibrates with the immobile ions (K+) in the electrolyte. 3) Analysis of other species by employing auxiliary solid phases (Type III). For example, the NOx sensor employing the NaNO2 as the auxiliary phase to equilibrate with the gas species (NO/NO2) and the conductive ion of the solid electrolyte.[71]
The EPS are fabricated by depositing two electrodes (reference and sensing) on each side of the solid electrolyte. YSZ, Na1+xZr2SixP3−xO12 (NASICON)[72] and Li3PO4 are the common adopted electrolytes for O2, CO2, NOx and VOCs detection. For the EPS detecting oxygen, it is necessary to use an external reference electrode (RE) (usually made of Pt), which works with a fixed reference oxygen partial pressure, thus the oxygen partial pressure difference can be determined. However, the sensor with external RE shows a more complex configuration and the sensor is hard to miniaturize. To solve this problem, the internal RE is developed. As shown from Figure 14a–c, with a Mn2O3 internal RE, the sensor structure is simplified from
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800488 (18 of 38)
www.advmattechnol.de
tubular to a planar-like rod-type and the sensor can still show excellent sensitivity and selectivity.[68aa] The character of the sensing electrode (SE) is a key factor that can affect the sensor
performance significantly, including material, configuration and even its size ratio to RE. A two layered Bi8Nb2O17/Pt open SE for CO2 sensor based on NASICON have reported exhibiting an enhanced selectivity as a result of the small inference from oxygen partial pressure (Figure 14d–f). The influence of the SE size has been investigated as shown in Figure 14g,h,[68au] the area as well as width ratio between SE and RE can affect the response and recovery time of the sensor.
Due to the limitation of the electrolyte and auxiliary phase choice, the applications of the EPS are often constrained. Therefore, the MPS is developed by taking advantage of the competing reactions on the sensitive materials (summarized in Table 9[33,67k,73]), viz., the catalysts of the reactions (analyte gas-O2 reaction and analyte gas-sensitive materials reaction). The mixed potential can be detected when the reaction rate of these two reactions are equal. Through designing/tuning the catalytic activities of the two electrodes with different materials, the electromotive force (EMF) can reflect the information of analyte gas.
There are three approaches to enhance the performance of MPS: the first one is enlarging the triple phase boundary (TPB) of the electrodes, many efforts have been made based on this principle including coarsening the electrolyte surface,[73y,ao,at,74] employing the impregnating method[75] and fabricating composite SE.[73aa,al,an] A YSZ electrolyte surface with porous micrometer-sized groove has been prepared by using the femtosecond laser direct writing technology. The fabricated sensor shows an enhanced performance, NO2 in range from 5 to 500 ppm can be effectively detected at 800 °C (Figure 15a–c). Besides that, a coating technique has been proposed to fabricate the YSZ electrolyte with porous surface as shown from Figure 15d–f,[73r] which provides a more convenience and promising way for the sensor fabrication. Secondly, by introducing the photoelectrochemical reaction on the TPB, the sensor performance can also be enhanced.[76] ZnO (SE) is irritated by UV light to regulate the photocatalytic activity, which ascribes to the good sensitivity as well as selectivity to various gas analytes (Figure 15g–j) in a YSZ electrolyte based SSES.[77] The last but the most directly method is developing new SE with enhanced catalytic activity. Recently, a CeO2 oxide based SE (CeO2–B2O3 (B = Fe, Cr)) has been developed for the mixed potentiometric NO2 sensor with good sensitivity, selectivity as well as long-term stability, shown from Figure 15k–p.[73au]
Unlike the EPS and MPS, in which the electrode is directly exposed to the gas atmosphere, the cathode of the amperometric gas sensor, and the gas is separated by a diffusion barrier layer. When the electrode has a negative voltage bias, the oxygen is pumped from the cathode to the anode side. The response of the sensor is diffusion limited current depending on the pumping rate and the diffusion flux of gas through the holes (summarized in Table 10[74,78]). Several factors influence the performance of the potentiometric sensors including the structure as well as the materials of the gas diffusion layer and the SE. For the diffusion layer, it can be porous or dense.[79] The porous diffusion barrier often shows poor mechanical strength, therefore, sensors with dense diffusion barrier have attracted more attentions. Mixed oxide-ion/electron conductor (MIEC) materials are the mostly studied dense

The impedancemetric gas sensor is a kind of sensors, which shows similar designation with the MPS (summarized in Table 11[80]). However, comparing with the MPS, the sensor signal is not the voltage between SE and RE but the impedance measured by the AC impedance spectroscopy technology.[81] The measured impedance data could be interpreted, using the equivalent circuit. Based on this approach, the electrochemical processes involved could be separated and the sensing mechanism investigated. The impedance type sensor for NOx detection is first proposed by Miura et al.[80b] The work principle is based on the corresponding relation between different impedance response and specific electrode process by measuring impedance at a certain frequency range to determine the NOx concentration. Nevertheless, the existence of O2 can still interfere with the sensing performance. To solve this problem, a dual frequency measurements method has been proposed by Martin et al.,[80e] which can successfully detect the NOx concentration with O2 background between 2% and 18.9%. It is found that the phase angle Θ shows more robust metric than the modulus of the impedance |Z|. By measuring the Θ of the sensor at 2 frequencies, the NOx concentration can be obtained. The SE materials and microstructure are also the key factors influencing the sensing performance. The works focusing on SE microstructure optimization have also been reported. Wang et al. have successfully fabricated NiOYSZ[80f ] and Pd doped perovskite oxide SE[82] by the impregnation method. A laminated-type ZnO/SnO2-SE with ZnO powder (0–30 wt%) added in the SnO2 layer has also been proposed, and reveals excellent selectivity to 100 ppb C3H6 as well as high sensitivity, even in the humid environment (+1.35 vol% H2O) (Figure 17a–f).[80m]

sections.heading: 3.4. Quartz Crystal Microbalance Based Gas Sensor
sections.text:
Quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), a kind of mass transducers, can detect the gases through the shift of the resonant frequency caused by gas absorption/desorption induced changes of the mass of sensitive materials, which follows the Sauerbrey’s equation. The two important things for QCM are: 1) the AT crystal cut along the orientation of 35°15′ from the Z axis of the crystal let the QCM achieve resonance frequencies
An array of 12 QCMs coated with different metal complexes of porphyrins and corroles have been developed by the Paolesse et al. as shown in Figure 18a.[85] The typical response of the Ru-TPP based QCM in this system (LibraNose, University of Ro me “Tor Vergata” and Technobiochip) is shown in Figure 18b.[86] However, the sensor units are exactly nonselective, which limits the ability of discrimination of the sensor arrays. Molecularly imprint polymers (MIPs) can enhance the selectivity of the QCM as shown in the insert of Figure 18c, and its working mechanism is making the sensitive materials with the analytes in the fabrication and kicking out the analytes to form the specific sites of analytes by analogy with “one key-one lock” strategy (Figure 18c).[87] One of the useful methods to enhance the response of QCM is to make the sensitive materials porous as shown in Figure 18d.[84] SiO2 and ZIF-8 templated hollow nanocrystals (porphyrin-based shell) were synthesized and used as the sensitive materials. It clearly reveals that the stacking way caused by nanocrystal shapes greatly influence the response of QCM (e.g., the P-HMZnP (hexagon) achieve the highest performance) as shown in figure 18e.[88] Layer-by-layer assembled composites (SiO2-PAH-PAA) have been developed for environmental and human breath ammonia assessments. LODs approaching 2 ppm aqueous ammonia (equivalent to ≈0.5 ppm gaseous) were achieved, which allow breath ammonia at pathological levels (greater than 3 ppm) to be measured (Figure 18f).[89] The recent representative advances are summarized in Table 12.[41f,85-86,88-90]
Frankly remarking, QCM is not the primary choice of e-nose. Indeed, in contrary to chemoresistor, FET, and SSES where

their alterations require some sorts of charge transfer and/ or materials change, the QCM responses to gas based on any forms of bindings of the gases onto the sensing layer, even the weak and ubiquitous van Der Waals interactions. Therefore, QCM is lack of selectivity and seldom used as a stand-alone component but rather as the supportive element of sensor arrays in an e-nose system.

sections.heading: 4. The Algorithm for e-Nose
sections.text:
The pattern recognition and classification techniques play an important role in e-nose system for distinguishing different types of gases based on the collected data which is a set of semi-independent variables. Statistical methods (e.g., PCA, hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA), principal component regression (PCR), discriminant factor analysis (DFA), analysis of variance between groups (ANOVA), partial least squares (PLS), soft independent modelling class analogy (SIMCA) and clustering algorithms) and AI techniques (they are, e.g., artificial neural networks (ANN), Inc., multilayer perceptrons (MLP), radial basis function networks (RBF), self-organizing maps (SOM), learning vector quantization (LVQ), and self-organizing competitive system or growing cell family of algorithms), fuzzy logic and fuzzy rules based algorithms, and genetic algorithms (GA)) have all been adopted in artificial olfaction with the rapid growth of the hardware performance both in exploratory and confirmatory types.[91]

Conventionally, the statistical methods can work alone to deal with the data of e-nose, and are still a popular way to process data.[91,92] However, choosing an appropriate algorithm is critical for obtaining good results, either because the algorithm lacks sufficient plasticity to model nonlinear data, or because a highly plastic model is over trained on an insufficient number of training data, which makes the data analysis too professional and not easy to handle.[91,92] Nonconventionally, AI techniques, e.g., ANN, have successfully solved many problems in the fields of pattern recognition that is quite similar with the function of human brain in the olfaction. The combination of statistical methods and AI are the further developing orientation for artificial olfaction.[93] A nondestructive e-nose integrating a neural network has been adopted to detect the penicillin G in goat milk. LDA, Fisher discriminant analysis (FDA) and multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural networks have been employed to differentiate the concentrations of penicillin G in samples.[94] e-nose (MOSES II) for distinguishing different fruits, i.e., strawberry, lemon, cherry, and melon classification has been demonstrated.[95] The neural network has been optimized using artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm, and there are two hidden layers with eight inputs and four outputs in this neural network. Back propagation ANN (BP-ANN) and ANN-ANN can achieve the performance of 60% and 76.39% in the collected data, respectively. RBF and PCA combined with RBF are also adapted to predicting freshness of tilapia fillets in cold chain.[96] High accuracy, fast speed, simple to train, low memory requirements, robust to outliers and produce a measure of uncertainty are the soul of an ideal algorithm. Recently, extreme Learning Machines (ELM), a.k.a., the overlimit learning machine, have been developed for solving the single hidden layer feedforward neural network. Traditional feed forward neural networks (such as BP-ANN) need to set manually a large number of network training parameters. This algorithm only needs to set the structure of the network without setting other parameters, which means easy to implement. The weight of the input layer to the hidden layer is determined randomly. The algorithm does not need to be adjusted during the execution of the algorithm, and the weight of the hidden layer to the output
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488
www.advancedsciencenews.com

www.advmattechnol.de
layer only needs to solve a linear equation group, so the calculation speed can be improved. For abnormal odors cancellation, two simple and efficient methods have proposed: one method is a self-expression model (SEM) trained with target odor data for coding; the other method is SEM based on ELM.[97] The advantage of ELM that solving the single hidden layer feedforward neural network is exploited. The sensor drift would happen when it has been operating for a long time. In order to compensate the sensor drift, a domain adaptation ELM has proposed for gas classification in electronic nose system.[98] By learning a classifier from source and target domains, two classification methods based on ELM have been proposed. The collected data has proved the effectiveness of these two methods to deal with sensor drift. Based on this gas sensor, Qiu et al. exploited ELM to distinguish two food additives, i.e., benzoic acid and chitosan.[99] This work shows that e-nose integrating with ELM can achieve fast and cost-effective detection, which greatly facilitates reliable and real-time data classification by using on-chip learning rule. However, the accuracy of ELM is limited as the price of simplified hidden layer and fasten computation speed. If the high accuracy is the most required goal, deep learning is prior to other methods, especially with massive data. Deep learning is a branch of machine learning, and it is an algorithm that attempts to abstract feathers from data, using multiple processing layers that consist of complex structures or multiple
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488

nonlinear transforms. The advantage of deep learning is to replace the manual acquisition features with unsupervised/ semi-supervised feature learning and hierarchical feature extraction efficient algorithms. Wang et al. have embedded the continuous restricted Boltzmann machine (CRBM) into the e-nose.[100] This CRBM based electronic nose can adjust its parameter by itself corresponding to the new input data. MLP
have been used to estimate the concentration of different kinds of gases simultaneously.[101] Two structures, i.e., single MIMO (SMIMO) and multiple MIMO (MMIMO) have been successfully utilized for detecting the concentration of the indoor air contaminants. A 38 layers deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) is also demonstrated effective to classify different kinds of gases after training.[102] When the sensor drift exists, the classification performance in e-nose even can be improved based on deep learning method.[103] However, deep learning methods depend on the hardware performance and lots of data. Therefore, how to design effective deep learning based methods for gas classification with low train overhead is an important problem to study in the further.
It is worthy to note that, in the future, the more advanced algorithm (e.g., deep learning) needs to develop with high performance hardware, whilst, a trade-off between the computation speed and the accuracy need to be well considered. Otherwise, it would not help too much if only improving the algorithm without the development of high-performance sensors, especially in stability and reproducibility.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
This article has reviewed the applications of e-nose in various fields, the R&D of advanced materials used to buid the sensors, and the algorithm for recognitions and classifications. Their relationships are given in Figure 19. Sensors work in special applications at different temperatures ranges (green

arrow: room temperature, red arrow: high temperature, purple arrow: both room and high temperature). For example, chemoresistors and FET can work at both room and high temperature. Solid-state electrochemical gas sensor can work at high temperatures only with the limitation of the solid electrolyte. QCM always works at room temperature. In the viewpoint of applications, all the fields prefer to work at room temperature; however, the disease diagnosis, environmental monitoring and agricultural production also accept working at high temperature. A brief comparison to these 4 types of sensors has been given according to the other aspects of sensitivity, selectivity, speed, cost, size (Table 13). Figure 19 and Table 13 could shed a light to choose or design e-nose for special/aimed applications.
With the prospect of mimicking biological olfaction, the limits of e-nose technology in the further development were clearly realized and pointed primarily to the sensing unit, sampling system, and measurement and data processing component. The challenges are summarized as follow:
• Currently, most of all reported sensors in lab can detect ppm or sub ppm level gas. But some applications, e.g., breath diagnosis, explosives detection, etc., need the sensor with high sensitivity to extend the LOD to ppb even to ppq. Therefore, seeking after an effective way for enhancing the sensitivity of sensor is necessary. Besides enlarging the surface area of the sensitive materials, multifield coupling to regulate the performance may be also a great way to improve the sensitivity, e.g., UV light irridation,[76] strain tuned piezoresistive effect,[104] strain induced additional piezoelectric gate voltage (Figure 20a–c),[105] etc. • The trend of precise odor/molecular recognition by e-nose is using interactive sensor arrays to replace single sensor unit because normally the selectivity of single sensing unit is insufficient. However, the selectivity and specificity of single unit is still highly desired. Besides that, high sensitivity, room working temperature, good stability, fast speed of response, and recovery are also critical for a sensing unit. The fundamental mechanism related to these benchmarks is the process of gas absorption–desorption on the surface and/ or the variation of intrinsic materials properties (e.g., chemical reaction,[66,106] polymer chain swell,[58] critical structural parameters of the sensing materials (the porosity, porous structure, film thickness, and uniformity in the film thickness),[107] etc.). A strong absorption or chemical reaction may lead to a good selectivity and/or sensitivity, but make the sensor hard to recover (Figure 20h).[66] The higher working temperature may fasten the recovery but also let the sensor deviate the optimum working temperature (inorganic materials based sensor), or change the crystalline of sensitive materials (polymer based sensor). The utilization of barrier height
dominated gas sensing behavior in Schottky contact can dramatically fasten the recovery and sensing, also work at room temperature with semiselectivity.[108] However, the large scale production of stable Schottky contact with the same barrier height is very challenge. How to design and fabricate a sensor with good trade-off between these correlative factors for meeting the demands of specific application is still a great challenge. • The baseline of sensor will drift due to the condition variations of environment including temperature change, humidity change, pressure change, etc. Till now, many detections still need to use ultraclean air or N2 to be the carrier gas, which makes the on-line/in situ sensing difficult. Otherwise, in the practical application, the analytes are always mixed with interference gas, their sensing signals need to be calibrated. Although e-nose system can add additional temperature, humidity and pressure sensor to calibrate the drift, in addition, covering MOF or molecular layer on the sensing materials are demonstrated effective for reducing the influence of interference gases. The environment effectless e-nose is urgently desired but still challenging. • The sampling of the real analyte is quite hard to keep uniform, and this process is very operational, which makes the results deviated and hard to recognize. Therefore, an autosampling facility is highly needed. Meanwhile, little absorbent materials can selectively collect and preconcentrate the analyte to ease the e-nose recognition. MOFs or COFs with tunable pore sizes and functional group may selectively absorb specific gas.[109] If it can also release the gas with acceptable working condition, this issue may be solved. • The synchronous signal measurement of sensor arrays with high accuracy are still problematic. Nowadays, the solutions for synchronous measurement are: a) combining the switcher and sourcemeter; b) using a time clock to synchronous multisourcemeter work together; c) special designed measurement system. The first way is not expensive but not really synchronous. The switcher will waste time to switch from one sensor to another and delay to acquire data for precise measurement. The second way is exactly synchronous, but the accuracy is lower than that of sourcemeter, meanwhile, the cost of this kind of system is much higher than the first one. The third way is low cost and most suitable for mass production. Normally the measurement range only covers the required value, which is not suitable for research. • For the odor recognition, the time for establishing the data base is long due to the difficulty of gathering a representative and exactly right set of samples qualified by believable method (sensory panel, gas chromatography (GC), GC/mass spectrometry (MS)). If the algorithm and hardwares can be more advanced, it may let the e-nose work based on smaller database. • The minimization of the e-nose including the sensor, chamber and data acquisition and processing system[110] with optimized algorithm and module for smell recognition is still challenge. Many efforts and funds have been put into this direction, e.g., microelectromechanical system (MEMS) to reduce the size of gas sensors and integrate them as a system,[111] and sniff phone project of EU (Horizon 2020) using GNPs based sensor arrays. It is worthy to believe that
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800488 (32 of 38)
www.advmattechnol.de
when the electronics are minimized,[112] the whole size of the e-nose can be also reduced and finally be a small facility or an accessary of cell phone. • The fluildic behavior of gas flow on the sensor array is a lack of enough attentions, which actually influence the sensing performance. Obviously, the fluildic behavior of analyte gas do affect the sensing performance not only response but also recovery. If the sensing chamber structure of e-nose is well designed, the performance can be easily improved as shown in Figure 20d–f.[113] When the gas flow in a microfluidic chamber, the sensing performance will be further changed
as shown in Figure 20g.[114] Therefore, combining with the well-developed fluidic calculation method/software to design a suitable chamber/channel is valuable for e-nose system. • The power consumption and power source replacement are still challenges for continuous detection of e-nose. Selfpowered technology, connecting a power generator that can convert waste energy to electricity to sensor, is promising to solve this problem. However, the more effective way is to combine the sensitive materials to be a part of the power generator as shown in Figure 20i,j.[115] In this way, the output of generator is coupled with the sensing process, i.e., the
Adv. Mater. Technol. 2019, 4, 1800488
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800488 (33 of 38)
www.advmattechnol.de
generator itself can work as an all-in-one gas sensor without power source.[116] • In recent years, wearable gas sensors have been widely investigated and applied in robotics, healthcare and sensory simulation, such as electronic skins that can smell.[117] Making a device soft is a trend for most of the bioelectronic device.[118] However, how to make the e-nose more flexible and wearable without the cross-talk to strain remains a challenge. Introducing intrinsic nanostructure (e.g., nanowrinkles) may be an effective way.[57f ]
After solving these challenges, e-nose promises to replace or achieve the most olfaction related work and work even better than human beings, which is valuable and desired for the applications or revolutions in AI, and the IoT. The advance in our knowledge in all endeavors of e-nose researches can be a foundation and useful experience for analysis chemistry (especially gas analysis), surface science, materials, fluidic mechanics, ANN, microelectronics, etc.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/admt.201800488 on receptors located in the nasal cavity.[2] Molecules carrying specific odors enter through the turbinate bones to touch the olfactory epithelium containing nerve cells and their hair-like endings, trigeminal endings, and supporting cells (Figure 1a).[2] Odorant molecules are absorbed by the olfactory epithelium mucus, diffuse onto the cilia of the olfactory cells, and interact with a specific receptor on its surface, probably complexing with odor-binding proteins thereby depolarizing the receptor cell. Simultaneously, an electrochemical potential is provoked and transmitted to the olfactory bulb along the axon direction and thence to the higher brain centers where the signals are interpreted in terms of the character and intensity of the odor (Figure 1b).[3] After learning/ training, the human brain can remember different potentials/signals caused by different odorants molecules, which endows human beings with an ability to recognize odors. Inspired by the olfactory system, artificial devices that combine arrays of chemical sensors with pattern recognition techniques, commonly termed “electronic nose” (e-nose), have been explored for use as inexpensive chemical point detectors. Proposed by Dodd and Persaud at Warwick University in UK in 1982,[4] this e-nose technology has been further developed Artificial olfaction, i.e., e-nose, plays a critical function in robotics by mimicking the human olfactory organ that can recognize different smells that correlate with a range of fields, including environment monitoring, disease diagnosis, public security affairs, agricultural production, food industry, etc. The advances in the artificial olfaction (electronic nose) technology and its applications are concisely reviewed herein. Three main elements are investigated and presented, with an emphasis on the emerging sensors and algorithm of the artificial neural network in the relevant fields. The first element is the diverse applications of e-nose in medical care, food industry, environment monitoring, public security affairs, and agricultural production. The second element is the investigation of the sensors in e-nose and representative and promising advances, which is the building block of e-nose through mimicking the olfactory receptors. The third element is the introduction to the algorithm of the artificial neural network to serve in the recognition of the pattern of odors (i.e., their chemical profiles). Promises and challenges of the separately reviewed parts and the combined parts are presented and discussed. Ideas regarding further orientation and development of the e-nose system are also considered.
